title: Scripted messages delivered by nurses and radio changed beliefs, attitudes, intentions, and behaviors regarding infant and young child feeding in Mexico
authors: Monterrosa EC, Frongillo EA, de Coss√≠o TG, Bonvecchio A, Villanueva MA, Thrasher JF, Rivera JA
population: Pre/Post test design with mothers  of healthy children between 6 and 24 mos in 6 communities in Morelos and 3 control communities in Puebla
intervention: 5 scripted radio messages using theory of planned behavior and a social marketing approach to improve infant and young child feeding
outcomes-bf: Beliefs, attitudes, and intention, but not social norms, about IYCF significantly improved in the intervention communities compared with control
outcomes-behavior: Significant pre-/post changes in the intervention communities compared with control were reported for breastfeeding frequency, and consumption of vegetables  and beef and thicker consistency of chicken and vegetable broths
smbc: 5:  Customer orientation, Theory, Insight, Segmentation, Method mix

title: Addressing inequities in access to health products through the use of social marketing, community mobilization, and local entrepreneurs in rural western Kenya
authors: Harris JR, Patel MK, Juliao P, Suchdev PS, Ruth LJ, Were V, Ochieng C, Faith SH, Kola S, Otieno R, Sadumah I, Obure A, Quick R
journal: International Journal of Population Research, 2012, ID 470598
population: Households in 60 villages in Western Kenya
intervention: Social marketing of Water Guard water treatment products, Sprinkles, and insecticide-treated bednets through Safe Water and AIDS project vendors
outcomes-bf:
At FU1, greater proportions of respondents from intervention households than comparison households who received SWAP vendor visits reported purchasing WaterGuard (14% versus 2%, P < 0.0001), ITNs (3% versus 1%, P < 0.04), and
Sprinkles (36% versus 6%, P < 0.0001) from SWAP vendors
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Monitoring the marketing, distribution, and use of Sprinkles micronutrient powders in rural western Kenya
authors: Suchdev PS, Laird R, Obure A, Were V, Ochieng C, Ogange L, Owuor M, Ngure F, Quick R, Juliao P, Jung C, Teates K, Cruz K, Jefferds MED
population: Longitudinal cohort trial of 550 children aged 6 to 35 months at baseline and 451 children aged 18 to 47 months at follow-up
outcomes-bf: Awareness of Sprinkles was high (98%) at follow-up
outcomes-behavior:
At follow-up, 35% of the mothers reported that
their child had used Sprinkles in the past 24 hours, and 61% reported use in the past 7 days
smbc: 5: Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

title: Social mobilization and social marketing to promote NaFeEDTA-fortified soya sauce in an iron-deficient population through a public-private partnership
authors: Wang B, Zhan S, Sun J, Lee L
population: Women older than 20 years of age and young children aged from 3 to 7 years
intervention: Social mobilization and social  marketing of iron fortified soya sauce
outcomes-bf:
After 1 year, most knowledge and attitudes had changed positively
towards the prevention and control of anaemia
outcomes-behavior: The percentage of women who adopted NaFeEDTA-fortified soya sauce increased from 8.9% to 36.6%
outcomes-health: After 2 years, Hb levels had increased substantially, by 9.0 g/l in adult women and 7.7 g/l in children
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Methods mix
